[gentle] Sofia, mi amor, my little Sofia who used to, um, dance on my feet while I hummed your mother's favorite, [nostalgic], songs in our kitchen that, well, smelled like fresh tortillas every, umm, Sunday morning.

[pleading] Let me see you just once, even from, [desperate], across a restaurant where you don't have to speak to me or, [begging], acknowledge that this broken fieldworker is your father. [sobs quietly]

[firm] The security guard will have your name and, um, there's a coffee shop on the, [wavering], first floor where we can, well, sit for exactly one hour to, umm, see if twenty years can fit into sixty minutes.
[hopeful] I still remember how you take your coffee with two, [tender], sugars and just a drop of milk, um, unless that changed too along with, well, everything else I missed. [pause]
